I wish I could recommend your comment a thousand times, Kevin!

Happy New Year to you!

You seem to be saying that the standard 26 weeks is no longer sufficient to achieve the goals of unemployment insurance.

If you feel that is the case, then the most appropriate position for you to advocate are state-level revisions in their unemployment compensation programs, e.g., higher payroll deductions, continuing to fund it as a benefit (funded by the same people who will benefit from it), rather than espousing an approach that perniciously transforms it into an entitlement program.

If you'd taken a retail job you might never have gotten back to where you are now. And you would have taken a job from someone else that needed it. A lot of commenters don't seem to get this: there haven't been enough jobs to go around. If you hadn't taken the benefits then someone else would have.

Let me be sure I understand this: I need to pay higher taxes so you don't have to dip into your savings or take a lesser job while looking for a suitable job. Do I have that right? What about my ability to save if I must pay higher taxes? Isn't savings done for just this reason - a "rainy day"?

Sorry, this is not how it's supposed to work...

I was unemployed for 13 months, starting in 2009, after being laid off on my 40th birthday when my company was sold. Fortunately, because I had the extended unemployment benefits to survive on, I didn't need to dip into savings and I was able to continue my career, with a relevant job I found more than a year after being let go. I now have a decent job that pays slightly more than I earned before the Big R hit. But without the extended benefits, I would have had to take a retail job for significantly less income and no stability, and wouldn't have remained independent. The extended benefits empowered me during my long job search. The standard 26 weeks isn't enough time nowadays to continue a career.

"Conflict of interest" would be putting it politely, perhaps unwarrantedly so.

Unfortunately, such behavior has become fairly common in the upper middle-class. This situation is no different than doctors taking payments from drug and device companies, whose products they tout to patients. No different than financial institutions taking payments from companies they steer clients to (e.g. Edward Jones getting kickbacks from Putnam Investments.) Little different than upper level clergy shuffling around known pedophile priests from parish to parish.

What makes something merely "possible-conflict-of-interest" as opposed to "illegal?" It boils down to who writes he laws. Commodity traders do not need class action suits to defend their interests. Academics on corporate payrolls do not need to organize and hire lobbyists. The hands that feed them take care of that.

I say "upper middle-class" because, off hand, I can't thing of coal miners, janitors, mailmen, and maids acting this way.
Or researchers funded by drug companies would not find results that favor those companies. Or physicians who receive "inducements" would not prescribe those drugs more often.

Of course the financial rewards these faculty get from Wall Street don't influence their research.  Just like professors who got lavish gifts from their students wouldn't be influenced when it came time to give out grades.  The difference is that universities have rules against the latter, but not the former.

"Mr. Pirrong, Mr. Irwin and other scholars say that financial considerations have not influenced their work. ..."
This flies against the basic aspects of human behaviour. These researchers and their employers are ignoring a key aspect of academia- ethical behaviour, and don't appear to realize that they have to hold themselves to a much higher standard than the one prevailing in the corporate world. Further, research in Finance and trading does not involve expensive laboratories or multi-million dollar equipment- therefore these researchers could have accomplished their work without being funded by the industry.
Getting funding for research is becoming more challenging- however this is no excuse for even giving the perception of being compromised. The fact that the industry these researchers are supporting has caused serious damage at times and is controversial only adds to the perception of "research and results for hire."

Self selection should not be ignored.
There are many professors who believe in very little regulation. They will certainly be sought out by organizations that believe similarly. Similarly, there are many organizations that believe in more regulation and to support their views, there are many professors. This is the nature of a developed country. I read these articles and think, 'what is new?'

Che Beauchard is right about the management picture, which is frightening (and which is subject to no control by the public, despite elections). She or he is wrong in suggesting by "individual professors and researchers" that there are only a few such people; they are, I believe, the majority. Whether that will be true in 20 years is less clear; if management seizes control of all functions including curriculum and research agendas from professors, the professors will have little discretion to choose their own agendas. We differ, therefore, in assessing the present situation but not in our worry about the future.

I am constantly astonished that the U.S., whose higher education is imitated all over the world (from Europe to China), is busy dismantling it. What is the motivation? It is not shortage of revenue; it is the refusal to tax the sources of wealth, i.e., the wealthy, in fair proportion to their wealth. (I say "wealth" as shorthand for assets and income both.) That leads me to conclude that our wealthy are indeed in control and are acting to reduce their own taxes while undermining the public good, or as our Constitution has it, "the general welfare".

I think that the vast majority of us want to run the financial pirates, banksters, corporate buyout vultures, and speculators out of town on a rail. However, if all of the latent desire for reform means nothing if we don't have a way to organize it. To use a lever, you need a place to stand.

We all know our politicians, of both parties, are wholly owned subsidiaries of the 1%. The mainstream TV news is a joke - a platform for integrated marketing of the owning conglomerate's latest films and jee-jaws. The NSA has an eye on the internet. The churches, clubs, social groups have all dwindled into nothing over the last thirty years (Read "Bowling Alone"). The unions are on life support. The major parties are nothing but Coke vs. Pepsi, with both owned by Wall Street.

If you never worked at a university, maybe you could be excused for thinking that there was one place left where smart, objective people, unsullied by the need to placate ultra-rich, could tell us all the Truth.

Ha ha. Just kidding. The universities are run by the boards and the big-money donors, who are one and the same, and by the MBA hucksters that speak their language.

KJ, I think that most of the people writing in to say that divorce is wrong if there are small children involved are probably people whose parents divorced when they were children and who experienced first-hand the terrible loss and disorientation and torn-in-two feelings that resulted. For a long time, probably since the divorce surge in the 1970s, the dominant narrative has been the divorce actually isn't so bad for kids -- yes, there's loss, there's adjustment, but in the end it's better than having unhappy parents, the story goes. This view is really everywhere, voiced most strongly, of course, by parents who have divorced and want to minimize/downplay the harm they have done others; the voices of the kids themselves were really drowned out. The experience and pain of the child was discounted as something passing, and kids' resilience was always emphasized. So those strong reactions you see in the comments section are probably mostly from those of us who weren't heard when we were five, or ten, or fifteen, but instead had to listen to lots of adults agreeing that blowing up our family lives was actually the best thing for everyone.

Also, it's crazy to talk about how happy divorced parents are better than unhappy married parents because these happy divorced parents are few and far between. Research shows that most people aren't happier as divorced singles or in second marriages than they were in their first marriages (not including abusive situations, of course).

Just think how windowless Krugman's world must be for him to imagine that there's nobody else in the universe except fellow Keynesians and a caricature of the Chicago school. Sad.

Of course wage stickiness is real. Of course that should be taken into account. But oversimplifications aren't helpful, and getting morally outraged at people who deny the sweeping conclusions that you draw from your ridiculously oversimplified models is just plain childish.

Wages do usually fall in recessions and their aftermaths, in real terms. Often that happens universally through inflation and/or currency depreciation (of which Krugman generally approves). Nominal wage cuts are in fact also common but never anywhere close to universal. They often come during the recovery period as people are rehired at lower wages than they were let go.

Are wage declines during and just after recessions good or bad? Both. Take for example the GM and Chrysler bailouts, which Krugman I assume approved of. What really happened there was the government bribed the unions into finally accepting two-tiered wages. The wages of new hires fell by around half, the total value of all kinds of compensation by even more. And that's the real reason why American car brands are back.
